sub_subject.name: Literature by Tradition & Region
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Literature by Tradition & Region (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify stories that talk about God and prayer.
Name Christian heroes in American history stories.
Identify the 'I Have a Dream' speech.
Name the Declaration of Independence.
Identify stories about American folk heroes (e.g., Johnny Appleseed).
Name famous American authors like Dr. Seuss or Laura Ingalls Wilder.
Identify a mask used in plays.
Name a play as a story acted out on stage.
Identify the Trojan Horse.
Name Odysseus as a man who traveled a long time.
Identify Aeneas as the hero who started Rome.
Name Rome as a city with many stories.
Identify stories about orphans or London fog.
Name Charles Dickens.
Identify Narnia as a land with a Lion King.
Name Aslan as a picture of Jesus.
Identify 'The Pilgrim's Progress' (Little Pilgrim's Progress).
Name Christian as a man traveling to the Celestial City.
Identify the Tortoise and the Hare.
Name the moral (lesson) of the story.
Identify a myth as an old story about how things began.
Name Hercules or Thor.
Identify fairy tales from France (Cinderella) and Germany (Hansel and Gretel).
Name Pinocchio (Italy) or Pippi Longstocking (Sweden).
Identify stories about Anansi the Spider (Africa).
Name Mulan (China) or Aladdin (Middle East).
Recall that the Pilgrims came to worship God.
Observe that faith was important to early Americans.
Recall that words can change the world.
Listen to a famous speech and say how it sounds.
Recall stories set in the early days of America.
Observe how life was different in pioneer stories.
Recall that plays can be funny or sad.
Observe a Greek theater (amphitheater).
Recall that ancient Greeks believed in many gods.
Observe pictures of Greek warriors.
Recall the story of Romulus and Remus.
Observe Roman statues and togas.
Identify knights, castles, and dragons in stories.
Name King Arthur and Robin Hood.
Recall poems about nature and flowers.
Observe that children in old stories dressed differently.
Recall that Aslan died and came back to life.
Observe that good wins over evil.
Recall that the Bible is the best book.
Observe maps of the journey to heaven.
Recall that animals act like people in fables.
Observe that slow and steady wins the race.
Recall that these are made-up stories, not Bible stories.
Observe that people wanted to understand the thunder and sea.
Recall that stories come from many countries.
Observe different settings in pictures.
Recall that people tell stories everywhere.
Observe art styles from different cultures in books.
Identify Shakespeare as a famous writer of plays.
Name Romeo and Juliet.
Write a simple fable.
Defend the utility of simple stories to teach complex truth.
Summarize a biography of a famous American Christian.
Explain the moral lesson in a story by a Christian author.
Explain the role of faith in the Abolitionist literature (Uncle Tom's Cabin).
Defend the Christian worldview against the skepticism of Stephen Crane.
Summarize the Preamble to the Constitution.
Explain what the Gettysburg Address was about.
Explain the purpose of the Federalist Papers (introductory).
Defend the literary quality of America's founding documents.
Summarize a story from the Colonial or Pioneer era.
Explain the difference between a Tall Tale and a true story.
Categorize stories by time period (Revolution, Civil War, Modern).
Explain the impact of the Great Depression on literature (Steinbeck).
Defend the literary merit of the 'Great American Novel' (e.g., Gatsby or Moby Dick).
Summarize the story of Antigone (simplified).
Explain the difference between a Comedy and a Tragedy.
Act out a scene from a Greek myth.
Explain the concept of Hubris (pride).
Defend the enduring relevance of Greek themes.
Summarize the cause of the Trojan War (Helen).
Explain the Cyclops story.
Map Odysseus' journey home.
Explain the role of the gods in the epics.
Defend the literary mastery of Homer's oral composition.
Summarize the story of the Aeneid (escape from Troy, founding Rome).
Explain why Romans wanted a hero story.
Explain how Rome copied and changed Greek stories.
Defend the rhetorical skill of Cicero.
Recall that stories were told out loud before books.
Observe pictures of old manuscripts.
Summarize 'A Christmas Carol'.
Explain the difference between city life and country life in stories.
Read poems by Wordsworth or Stevenson.
Explain the concept of the 'Byronic Hero'.
Defend the moral seriousness of George Eliot or Thomas Hardy.
Summarize 'The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe'.
Explain the 'Deeper Magic' (Atonement).
Explain the concept of 'Sub-creation' (Tolkien).
Defend the use of fantasy to tell the truth.
Summarize the plot of Pilgrim's Progress.
Explain the allegories (Slough of Despond, Vanity Fair).
Read biographies of great Christians (Luther, Foxe's Martyrs).
Explain why Christians write books to explain their faith.
Defend the literary merit of Christian classics.
Summarize the Boy Who Cried Wolf.
Explain what a 'moral' is.
Explain the universality of fables.
Summarize a Norse or Greek creation myth.
Explain why ancients created myths (to explain nature).
Categorize myths by culture (Norse, Greek, Egyptian).
Explain the difference between Myth and History.
Defend the historicity of the Gospel against the 'Christ-myth' theory.
Summarize a story by Hans Christian Andersen.
Explain the story of Heidi or The Swiss Family Robinson.
Locate the country of origin for a story on a map.
Defend the universal themes in Cervantes' 'Don Quixote'.
Summarize a Jataka Tale or a story from 1001 Nights.
Explain a Haiku poem.
Read a biography of a missionary in Asia or Africa.
Explain the oral tradition of the Griot.
Recall that people watched plays in a special theater.
Listen to a poem with rhyming words.
Compare a secular view of nature with a Christian view.
Apply lessons from 'Pilgrim's Progress' (often read in early America).
Analyze the sermons of Jonathan Edwards ('Sinners in the Hands...').
Interpret the religious struggle in Flannery O'Connor's stories.
Connect the poetry of Anne Bradstreet to Puritan theology.
Compare a speech by Washington with a speech by Lincoln.
Apply the idea of 'Liberty and Justice for All'.
Analyze the rhetorical devices in Patrick Henry's 'Give Me Liberty'.
Interpret the biblical references in MLK's speeches.
Connect the Declaration of Independence to Enlightenment thought.
Compare the setting of 'Little House on the Prairie' with today.
Analyze the themes of survival and independence in American fiction.
Interpret the mood of Edgar Allan Poe's short stories.
Connect Mark Twain's humor to the culture of the South.
Compare a movie script with a play script.
Analyze the conflict between God's law and Man's law in Antigone.
Interpret the concept of the 'Tragic Flaw' (Hamartia).
Connect the chorus to the role of the narrator.
Compare the Greek heroes (strong, proud) with biblical heroes (faithful).
Analyze the character of Achilles (Rage).
Interpret the concept of 'Xenia' (Hospitality).
Connect the epics to the history of Ancient Greece.
Compare Aeneas (duty) with Odysseus (cleverness).
Apply the idea of duty to family and country.
Analyze the theme of 'Pietas' (Duty) in the Aeneid.
Interpret Cicero's speeches on duty and friendship.
Connect Virgil's writing to the reign of Augustus Caesar.
Summarize the story of Beowulf (retold).
Explain the Code of Chivalry.
Categorize stories as legends or myths.
Explain the shift from Old English to Middle English.
Defend the literary complexity of 'Sir Gawain and the Green Knight'.
Compare Alice in Wonderland with realistic stories.
Analyze the social critique in Dickens (Oliver Twist, David Copperfield).
Interpret the nature poetry of Keats and Shelley.
Connect the Gothic novel (Frankenstein, Dracula) to fears of the time.
Compare Narnia with Middle Earth (Hobbit).
Apply the courage of the Pevensie children.
Analyze the Christian worldview in Lord of the Rings (Providence, King returning).
Interpret the Space Trilogy by C.S. Lewis.
Connect fiction to the 'True Myth' of the Gospel.
Compare Augustine's conversion story with Paul's.
Analyze the Screwtape Letters (temptation).
Interpret the confessions of St. Augustine.
Connect The Hiding Place (Corrie ten Boom) to suffering.
Compare two fables with similar lessons.
Analyze the human behaviors criticized in fables (greed, pride, laziness).
Interpret the political context of Aesop (slave speaking truth to power).
Connect fables to the Proverbs.
Compare the chaotic gods of myth with the Holy God of the Bible.
Analyze the hero's journey (Monomyth) structure.
Interpret the worldview behind a myth (Fatalism, Polytheism).
Connect myth to the human longing for the transcendent.
Compare a French fairy tale with a German one.
Analyze the moral dilemmas in Les Misérables (adapted).
Interpret the short stories of Tolstoy or Chekhov.
Connect 'The Three Musketeers' to history.
Compare a Native American legend with a Bible story.
Analyze the themes in 'Things Fall Apart' (Chinua Achebe).
Interpret the cultural context of 'The Good Earth' or 'Cry, the Beloved Country'.
Connect Haiku and Tank poetry to Zen aesthetics (and contrast with Christianity).
Summarize the plot of a Shakespeare play (e.g., Midsummer Night's Dream).
Explain what a Sonnet is.
Explain the structure of a Shakespearean tragedy.
Defend Shakespeare's insight into human nature.
Explain the concept of a 'translation'.
Defend the value of reading literature in translation to build empathy.
Evaluate the theological depth of Marilynne Robinson or Walker Percy.
Evaluate the logical structure of the Declaration of Independence.
Evaluate the worldview of Transcendentalism (Emerson/Thoreau) vs. Christianity.
Evaluate Aristotle's definition of tragedy (Catharsis).
Evaluate the morality of the Greek gods vs. Yahweh.
Evaluate Ovid's Metamorphoses as a source of myth.
Compare the legend of King Arthur with historical reality.
Analyze the hero cycle in Beowulf.
Interpret the Canterbury Tales (selected/adapted) as social satire.
Connect the Arthurian Romances to Christian allegory.
Evaluate the Industrial Revolution's impact on Victorian literature.
Evaluate the works of Dorothy Sayers or Flannery O'Connor.
Evaluate Chesterton's 'Orthodoxy' or Lewis's 'Mere Christianity'.
Evaluate the ethics of fables (pragmatic vs. moral).
Evaluate C.S. Lewis's view of Christianity as the 'Myth that became Fact'.
Evaluate Dante's 'Divine Comedy' through a theological lens.
Evaluate the worldview of Confucius or Lao Tzu in Chinese literature.
Compare a play script with a story book.
Apply a famous quote from Shakespeare to a situation.
Analyze the character development in Macbeth or Julius Caesar.
Interpret the religious allegory in Spenser's 'Faerie Queene'.
Connect the King James Bible to the development of English prose.
Construct an essay on the 'Haunted' nature of Christianity in Southern Gothic lit.
Synthesize the tension between cultural Christianity and true faith in literature.
Synthesize the evolution of American political rhetoric.
Construct a timeline of American Literary movements (Puritan, Romantic, Realist, Modern).
Synthesize the American Dream concept across different authors.
Synthesize the influence of Greek drama on Shakespeare.
Construct a profile of the 'Homeric Hero'.
Synthesize the influence of The Odyssey on all future travel narratives.
Construct a comparison of the Iliad, Odyssey, and Aeneid.
Evaluate the pagan vs. Christian elements in Beowulf.
Construct a comparison of Jane Austen's social commentary vs. Brontë's emotionalism.
Synthesize the shift from Romantic idealism to Victorian realism.
Construct a theological critique of a modern novel.
Synthesize the sacramental view of nature in Christian fiction.
Construct a summary of Calvin's Institutes or Luther's Bondage of the Will.
Synthesize the development of Christian thought through literature.
Construct a modern fable for a current social issue.
Synthesize the fable genre across cultures (La Fontaine, Panchatantra).
Construct a comparative essay on Flood myths vs. Genesis.
Synthesize the study of mythology to understand cultural anthropology.
Synthesize the influence of the French Revolution on European lit.
Construct a comparative essay on Eastern vs. Western narrative structures.
Synthesize the post-colonial themes in modern African or Indian literature.
Evaluate Milton's theology in 'Paradise Lost'.
Construct a rhetorical analysis of a presidential inaugural address.
Construct an analysis of Oedipus Rex (Fate vs. Free Will).
Synthesize the medieval worldview through its literature.
Construct an analysis of Dostoevsky's 'Crime and Punishment'.
Construct a critical essay on Hamlet or Lear.
Synthesize the impact of the Reformation on English literature.
Synthesize the Stoic philosophy found in Roman literature.
Construct a translation/analysis of a passage of Chaucer.
